title: Probing Sub-Unit Cell Polarization Waves in Multiferroic Layered Oxides with EELS
content: Magnetoelectric multiferroic materials exhibiting interesting topological features such as coupled ferroelectric and magnetic domains, domain walls and higher order structures such as polar vortices have shown great promise for future low-power nanoelectronics and memory-storage applications [1]. Few materials show multiferroic behavior in a single phase and at room temperature, with Bi6TixFeyMnzO18 (B6TFMO) being one such material [2], making it an interesting system for exploring and exploiting the physical mechanisms and topologies formed due to this magnetoelectric coupling. The latter is achieved in this system by incorporating a small amount of magnetic cations (Mn, Fe) into the multilayer ferroelectric framework. The relatively high magnetic response arises due to the preferential partitioning of Mn and Fe cations toward the central region of the perovskite superlattice. While the cation distribution within the structure has been measured previously using Electron Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDX) [3], here we additionally show a sub-unit cell variation in the valency of these cations using Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (EELS), and the potential implications of this phenomenon on the materialâ€™s magnetic response is discussed.
